instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V05_S5: What is PP1V05_S5? PP1V05_S5 is a 1.05v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. On 2008-2009 15” and 17” Macbook boards, this often gets stuck at 0.3v due to a bad C7771 capacitor. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flickering Video, No Audio Device in System Pref
threads.message:
I have 220-2936, bongs, boots, charges, green light etc, all good.

The video flickers a couple time on initial boot and when in full screen video, since its Intel HD (not ATI or NVidia) I'd like to think it may be power instability rather than GPU issue.

I replaced C167D and C167E on <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> (from Donor), same result.

Additional Symptoms- System preferences shows no Audio Output or Input device (Boot chime works). Some bad keys on keyboard.

I am more concerned about correcting Video flicker before worrying about Audio etc.

Any Ideas? Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flickering Video, No Audio Device in System Pref
threads.message:
I had a look at <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> on scope, it measures 1.06 and it looks like there is about 10mV of 300KHz ripple on it.  I also checked PP3V3, it has no detectable ripple.  Not sure if thats normal or not.

Not sure if anything else I can check, or just call it bad GPU and turn it into a donor.  Any input.  Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flickering Video, No Audio Device in System Pref
threads.message: Obvious liquid damage if keyboard is bad. The audio device is probably a bad jack as usual. The video flicker is probably corrosion somewhere, could be the LCD. Check external video.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flickering Video, No Audio Device in System Pref
threads.message:
I checked external, same deal, same flicker.

The machine came from another shop, I don't think this original logic board for case as no liquid evidence on logic board, normal grime and dust so it hasn't been cleaned either.

I suppose a careful reflow of MCP couldn't hurt at this point.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flickering Video, No Audio Device in System Pref
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flickering Video, No Audio Device in System Pref
threads.message: My bad, PCH...  I assume the video signals are generated by the PCH and the T29 is only Driver circuits?  Is that correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flickering Video, No Audio Device in System Pref
threads.message: No, CPU handles most of the video processing. PCH just does converting to LVDS. As the problem is also external the CPU is most likely the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flickering Video, No Audio Device in System Pref
